instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_DIV: What is LCDBKLT_EN_DIV? LCDBKLT_EN_DIV must be low in order for the P channel MOSFET to have a lower voltage on the gate than is present on the source to allow backlight voltage to flow through the backlight circuit. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
I got a board in that had liquid damage on the lvds connector. it was pretty bad. I pulled the connector off, cleaned the area really well. Soldered a new connector on, 
As a persecution I also changed the back light fuse.

PINS 21 and 22 for the lvds connector  have the solder pads missing.
I bridged the pins together and ran a jumper to <CAPACITOR>C9796</CAPACITOR>.

I also measured the resistance on <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> 
<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> - 97k ohm
<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> - 194K ohm ( which is the 301k ohm) I have changed this resistor twice now and get the same measurement.

Fuse voltage on both sides - 10.9v

I also tried a known good screen same thing, image but no backlight. Where should I go from here. 

I included a picture of the jumper wire i ran for the missing solder pags on pins 21 and 22 [ATTACH]7525._xfImport[/ATTACH] .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
Have you confirmed this is not no backlight rather than no display?. Could you tell us the voltage on the LVDS connector itself? 
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
Yes If I hold the screen at the correct angle I can see an image on the screen, 

pin1 - 0
pin2 - 0
pin3 - 0
pin4 - 3.2v
pin5 - Sync .14v
pin6 - 3.2v
pin7- 3.2v

I did change <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR> and l9004 after I took these measurements and found out that im missing 3.2v on pin 2 and pin 3.
Still same readings after changing <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR> and L9004. 
Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message: What do pins 21 and 22 measure? lets work backwards.

threads.message:
Those pins measure 0.0v
I took the measurment on the pins them selves and also on <CAPACITOR>C9796</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9020</CAPACITOR> 0.0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
Firstly why are you using a 2936 screen connector on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>? i hope youve changed the cable too. 
voltage on this net? <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL>.
If 12V check <RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
Im using this connector because its all I have at the moment the other connectors are on order. This is not a permanent solution. Can I be causing additional damage using this connector? Youll  have to excuse some of my inexperience im still pretty new to logic board repair.

I measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> on <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>, from what I understand I should have 12v on PIN 1,2,5,6 and all those pins measure 1.3v

Thanks for your help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
The way this part of the circuit works is <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> is gated on pin 2 and 5. this pulls <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> to ground. When this is pulled to ground <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> create a voltage divider on <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL>. This gates <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> and allows voltage to pass. 

So you need to check the gate signals of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>, and the voltage on <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL>.

IIRC theres a via that can fail somewhere around here causing the issue but you should rule out <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
This is where my inexperience comes in. Understand the function of what you are talking about just not sure how to apply what you have asked me to do.
How do I check the gate signals of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>

I measured <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> - pin1 = 12.5v, pin2 = 12.1v
<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> - pin1 = 12.1v, pin2 = 12.0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message: okay we can establish the voltage is not being pulled to ground, So you need to check the voltage on pin 2 and pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message: LCD is not recognized as there is no 3V on pin 2 and 3 then the backlight will also not be enabled of course. Probably because you are using a wrong connector and not making contact.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message: If you have an image then your measurements are incorrect. Pin 2 and 3 must have 3V for that to happen

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message: I understand that, im more convinced now that the connector is causing a problem. Which is also causing incorrect measurements. Thanks guys ill let you know the measurements after replacing the connector with the correct one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight liquid damage
threads.message:
I confirm definitely. 
Last time I tried a 2936 lvds cable into a 3115 LB connector it worked at a certain point until the screen went all white and then black no more lcd. I found L9004 burned open.
